text: Tap; pours black with a khaki colored head; aroma of roasted coffee, malt, chocolate, and hints of vanilla; sweet taste with chocolate, coffee, milk, and a trace of vanilla; finish is dry with some coffee, roast malt, and a hint of alcohol warming

Tap. Pours opaque black, small beige head, decent lacing. Aroma is heavy mocha, ashtray, tobacco, cocoa, molasses. Flavor is medium sweet, fully bitter, heavy coffee, mocha and tobacco, lactose sugar, burned sugars. Full body, creamy mouthfeel, lingering ashy bitterness.
On tap at the Surly brew pub. Good roasty stout with the milk sweetness fairly present

Jet black pour with a single finger espresso head. Lots of lace present. Aroma is sweet, a little coppery. Creamy full mouth. Taste is full of sweet coffee. Reminds me of a cup of coffee with a little booze in it. Chocolate creeps in as well. Really nice beer, but I think the fermentation could have been a little bit cleaner. There are some boozy qualities to this that knock it down a notch.
2016 version. On tap at brewery. Pours black with tan head. Nose and taste are espresso, chocolate and milk sugar. Delicious.

On tap at the brewery. Dark brown pour with a brown head. Chocolate aromas. Silky smooth with dark chocolates, dark roasted malt, and delicious expresso notes. Really good body and mouthfeel. Feel like a much bigger stout. Lactose and caramel backbeats. Bravo.
Tap at brewery. Black with a lasting khaki head. Chocolate, malted milk balls,oatmeal and light roast coffee. Taste is fairly sweet with a dry coffee aftertaste. Medium body with a light sticky feel.
Tap at brewery, do brown with creamy head, big coffee aroma, sweet and velvety. Very good

Super strong coffee aroma, strong malty caramel sweetness, syrupy palate, nice lacing, roasted coffee aftertaste. Pretty perfect!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at grumpys. 12oz pour . Black with a small tan head. Vanilla chocolate nose. Very smooth. Bittersweet chocolate, nice complimentary flavors. Nice thickness. Well flavored, even if a bit fake. Delicious.

Huge beer. When it was at its coldest, I thought it was more of a barrel aged beer. It has a lot of sweetness and a vanilla edginess. As it warmed, I got much more of the espresso and there were moments that it could have been overpowering. The alcohol is noticeable. Very good, but didnt want too much of this. On tap at brewery.

Keg @ Surly. Deep brown pour with a lasting creamy tan head. Strong espresso nose. Substantial roast grain. Marshmallow and brown sugar. Flavor is rich and very creamy. Ashy roast, burnt brown sugar. Dark chocolate fudge. Strong espresso character. Moderately bitter finish. Harmonious, well structured. Easy to drink. Smooth, creamy body. Quite good.

On tap at the beer hall, pours a dark brown/black with a medium tan head. Big roasted espresso aroma, sweet milk chocolate and molasses. Taste of sweet milk chocolate with a heavy dose of roasted dry espresso, a touch of bitterness, slick and smooth on the palate. Great balance of sweetness and dry bitter roast. Perfection.

Tap at the source. Pours black, nice tan head. Aroma is very roasted, lots of coffee, some chocolate and lactose. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, really good. The roasted coffee is so robust but the lactose lends a brilliant element. Well done.

Bottle at Levis tasting. Really glad I got a pour of this one. Pours dark with quickly disappearing head. Aroma is espresso, some chocolate, roasted malts. Very good beer, wow. Sweet chocolate, smooth, coffee/espresso held up great. Really a good beer, hadnt had it since I joined Ratebeer, glad I got to try it again.
Black. Tiny tan head. Big coffee and green pepper aroma. Thick and chocolate coffee. Held up very well.
Bottle shared at LeviLOL tasting - thanks Indeed dude! Big coffee nose and a great coffee and sweet stout taste. Cool!!

Traded bottle, not sure how old this is these days. Really a wonderful sweet stout. Really fun stout to drink. Nice espresso notes throughout with the slightest hint of cream and sugar. Very well done and has lost nothing with a little age on it.
Sample from a friend. Strong smell of chili (probably the coffee), coffee, choclate. Similar taste but also sweet and creamy. Very nice beer, probably one of the best coffee-beers Ive had.

750 ml bottle sampled at RBSG 2010 via Puddintane maybe (notes). Pours dark brown to black with a small fine beige head. The aroma and flavor had a great roasted malt, chocolate, coffee espresso and mild smoked character. The sweetness works well with the bitterness from the coffee. Medium plus body with a smooth finish. Tasty.

Shared a bottle of this. Poured a near black color with a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet malt notes, coupled with some strange green peppers and something else strange that I cant put my fingers on. Flavor had notes of chocolate milk, light brown sugar, sweet notes. Flavor wins out over the smell!

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur de café avec une pointe de chocolat noir. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café avec une pointe de chocolat et de lactose. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #4957)
Had this bottle for three years and finally broke it open. Just incredible flavor. Sweet, thick,full bodied, and very enjoyable.

Bouteille de 750 ml, merci beaucoup à Fred. Arômes de lait au chocolat et de café. Robe noire et opaque, peu de mousse et effervescence assez faible. En bouche, on retrouve une forte impression de lait au chocolat. Malgré la présence du café, elle demeure relativement peu rôtie pour une Imperial Stout et les notes maltées portent surtout vers le cacao. Finale assez courte, douce et sucrée, peu amère. À cet âge, lalcool est très peu apparent. Une belle stout dessert, à boire en petite quantité.

Previous notes...Pours dark chestnut black with a tan head. The aroma brings chocolate and smoke, nice! There is a toasted malty backbone with a chocolate ending and some bitter flavors for sure all on a medium body.

House a great dark brown pour with a tall tan head that fades a bit, but coats the glass nicely. Aroma of chocolate, malt, lactose, and a bit of dark fruit and coffee. Taste starts with chocolate and then the coffee comes in full power and takes over, finishes with an excellent bitterness. One of my favorite beers from Surly.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aged I thought the palate was a bit weak. It is a nicely flavored beer, coffee, toffee, caramel sweetness, roasted malts, all intense but not overly boozy.

November 4, 2012 bottle from Heritage Liquor.  Damn I have been sitting on this one a while and finally decided to crack it with my crazy hot trophy wife for rating 1000.  Plus got the presidential election coming up so four is the magic number for the winner. Alright, time for the rating.  Poured into my Surly pint and it had that nitro look that is just awesome.  It was dark brown with lots of head that lasted and some lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, rich coffee and roasted malt.  Taste starts out sweet and milky, then moves into the roasted coffee and finishes slightly bitter.  Very smooth and creamy almost like a cask pour, and medium bodied.
Pours nice and dark with a thick coffee nose. It has a nice chocolate and coffee taste. A very nice beer.

A gift from drabmuh. Thanks Matt! Split with my wife last night.

A: Near black shade and dark brown at the crest of the beer. Small beige head that leaves a crema layer resting atop the liquid. There are random spots of lacing noticeable on the glass.

S: Heavily roasted malt, coffee, bitter chocolate, cocoa

T: The beer tastes pretty decent and has a few different nice flavors happening. The coffee aspect tastes a little too bitter to me. I wonder what kind of coffee was used in the brewing process. Nice notes of chocolate throughout the taste. There is not nearly as much of a lactic presence as I was expecting. Perhaps the roasted malt and coffee flavors have masked the milk portion of the beer.

M: Decent feel, though a bit too bitter. The bitterness continues into the finish and through to the aftertaste. Alcohol is hidden well.

D: A good beer and worth trying. Decent stuff.

750ml bottle. Rating #158. Cracked this open for my birthday. Dark black pour with a big creamy tan head with a lot of lacing left behind. Big roasty and ashy aroma with a nice little touch of sweetness in the end. Whoa, lots of stuff going on here, more roast, very roasty, its like bitter chocolate covered coffee beans. Very smooth, nice aftertaste, and a little sweet. Good stuff. (2412)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: pours jet black with a creamy mocha head. quite bitter with lots of chocolate and dark roasted malts. again, quite bitter. i was expecting this to be sweet however i found this quite bitter. lots of dark chocolate, espresso coffee, and roasted malts just dominating. nice full body, bitterness through out, and moderate to mild carbonation. this was not what i had expected but worked out to be even better. this was a chocolate and coffee stout through out. Reviewed on: 06-20-2010

Thanks to chewy08rx for sending me this beer as part of a big box full of Surly beers. 

The beer pours a dark brown to black color with a tan head. The aroma has a ton of strong coffee and chocolate notes, with some light smoke and heavily roasted malt. 

The flavor is more complex. I get a lot of coffee and lactose, as well as some roasted malt and some light chili pepper notes. Overall, the beer tastes quite a bit like malted milk balls. The alcohol is very well hidden and the beer is extremely drinkable and enjoyable. 

Thick, heavy, full mouthfeel and low carbonation. A great beer. Glad I got to try it.
(750ml bottle, courtesy of BMan1113VR)  Pours an opaque black body with spare beige head.  Aroma of coffee, pine, chocolate, and smoke.  Flavor of chocolate, coffee, lactose, and roasted malt.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2012 ah.... maze.....ing.  Wow.  Thanks Eric, couldnt have had a better birthday present.  Pours thick, dark and black with a small brown head.  The nose is black licorice, coffee, chocolate milk, resinous pine, nutmeg.  So complex.  Taste is rich.  Sweet with a great bitter balance.  The taste is like a barrel aged beer even though this isnt.  Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy, medium body with a huge aftertaste.  Decedant.

Bottle shared by Darren. Thanks for knocking off one of my wants!   An intense coffee stout with lactose.  There you go, that pretty much sums it up.  Rich in aroma and flavor.  Lots of dark coffee, bitter chocolate and some roast in the background.  Soft body with a smooth finish that ends with some lingering alcohol.  Really great beer!

Bottle @ Papsø. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and coffee aroma. Roasted malty sweetish chocolate and coffee flavor. Has a roasted malty coffee and chocoalte finish.

This beer has been aged in my cellar since purchase. Wanted to see how it would change with age. Its probably past its prime.

A - Pours jet black with a medium tan color head. Light lacing on glass and the head dissipated quickly.

S - Very sweet blackberry, currant, with espresso lightly in the background. The coffee has really mellowed out since last time i had this and the sweet berry smells are overpowering everything else.

T - The taste of this beer now reminds me of a chocolate covered blackberry mixed with espresso. Definately get the a smooth coffee finish but has mellowed out significantly since it was bottled. Alcohol present on the finish.

M - Smooth and perfect level of carbonation for the style, in my opinion. Can get the alcohol a bit on the backend.

O - Overall, at the time of release, this was one of my favorite Surly beers however it has changed significantly from what i had remembered. Its still a fabulous milk stout but in my opinion, this beer is past its prime, so if anyone has any, you should consider consuming it now. Im very surprised at how sweet/tart this beer has converted to, i dont remember it being so sweet orginally - most likely because the espresso was stronger and balanced it better.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-21-2012 18:23:49

22-MAR-2012, bottle @Papsø.
Almost black with no head.
Dusty coffee notes. Roast, espresso and almost bourbon like.
Taste the same with quite a smooth body.
Fine.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of coffee and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, lactose, and a bit of coffee, leading to a dry roasted finish.

75 cL bottle. Pours pitch black with a fully gone head. Aroma is dense herbal coffee and dark roasted malty. Dry coffee, toasted and caramelish. Light breadish note. Lasting coffee herbal finish. Coffee in a 75 cL bottle - nice...

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of Skyview. Pours an opaque black with a tiny beige head. Heavy coffee aroma in the dusty chilli sense. Medium body, sweet vanillaish roast, quite some malt astringency. Alcohol appears late. 220312

Waxed 750ml from an awesome BA trader. Pour is thick and black with a creamy, tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is big coffee, chocolate, vanilla and sweet milky caramels. Flavor is milk chocolate, espresso, light roasty malt with very well hidden alcohol. Full body with soft carbonation and a thick, creamy, lush mouth feel. This is an amazing beer, its exactly as I imagined it would be. Lots of chocolate, coffee, and cream without being overly sweet and so smooth and rich. So good.

From notes.  First reviewed 7/6/2011.  Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip. Thanks to Dunt for bringing this bottle.

Out of the bottle comes a mahogany brown, viscous liquid with ruby edges. A quick-fading brown head forms with the initial pour.

The aroma is full of balanced roast malt, nice full espresso and milk chocolate aroma, like chocolate covered espresso beans.

The flavor is very smooth, one of the key features I enjoy about milk stouts. It starts with some molasses sweetness and a sugary lactose flavor that lingers throughout. A milk chocolate presence turns from sweet to bitter as the sip progresses. The dark roasted malt starts to play a factor and a burst of espresso comes through, leading toward a bitter end. Just a touch of booze at the finish.

The mouthfeel is creamy although not over the top. The lactose adds an extra layer to the smoothness. There is a noticeable level of carbonation, maybe just a bit much, and there is a definite stickiness to the texture. All of this is wrapped in a fuller than medium body. To create a 10% milk stout that does not have an over the top body takes some great skill, and I definitely appreciate the effort.

This is a very enjoyable beer. The flavors blend very well together and the rich, creamy mouthfeel supports the flavor nicely.

Four pours pitch black with a two finger tan head.  Smooth looking head without much bubbles or crators.  Retention is good but over time goes down to a small lacing around the glass.

The smell on this beer is inviting.  Very sweet aroma mixed in with roasted malt and coffee.  Sweetness took the number one aroma in this beer followed by the coffee.  Hints of chocolate round out the smell.  Wow!  The way everything comes together just hit the spot for me.  If I could wake up to that smell everyday, everything would be right in this world.

At 10% abv you would think some kind of alcohol would come through on this beer but nope it doesnt.  Instead the espresso comes through like a champ.  Coffee and chocolate.  Then the sweetness comes in and lingers in with the rest of the ingredients and leaves just an awesome aftertaste.

Mouthfeel is thick and heavy bodied.  Perfect.  Just what you want from a big stout like this.

Cellar aged, on tap at the Bavarian Lodge, Black Friday 2011.  Ill never have this again so Ill give it my best review now.  Wow what a beer.  Definately the best stout I ever had.  Had this right after Darkness, and these are very close to each other, this is basically Coffee darkness.  Strong coffee smell.  Thick sweet coffee chocolate malty goodness.  Awesome.

Bottle from a trade with StoutFest. Pours black with brown head. Aromas of espresso, chocolate and roasted malts. Flavors of roasted malts, espresso and sweet milk chocolate. Medum to full body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Excellent!  Thanks Ramiro.

On tap at republic for beer school.  Dark black pour with huge beige head.  when it was being poured it looked like iced coffee. The aroma had major coffee notes with tons of sweetness. It was definitely a delicious taste. Very sweet. It was very smooth with a lingering coffee flavor. I love this beer.very excellent.

Bottle: &nbsp Nearly black, just a smidgen of light comes through on the edges, large frothy light brown head, 

nice lacing. &nbsp Fairly assertive sweet coffee aroma, definite beans, even a bit of dark bittersweet chocolate, 

hops, and alcohol. &nbsp Very smooth and rich on the tongue, wow, very silky... velvety in fact! &nbsp Strong coffee 

with a hefty dose of cream and sugar. &nbsp This blows most examples clean out of the water. &nbsp A little warming on 

the backside. &nbsp As it warms it develops more hop character on the backside. &nbsp Still cant get over how smooth 

this is. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are excellent! &nbsp Lingering coffee and hops, smidgen of peat and campfire. &nbsp 

Tasty stuff, and one I would recommend. &nbsp Thanks Bob!

In short: A bubbly old cup of cold coffee with milk and cream.  Meh.
How: Bottle 750ml, thick turquoise wax-top.  Consumed when a little bit more than one year of age.  Bottle sent to me by oakbluff, thanks a lot Scott
The look: Black body topped by a medium tan head with medium retention
In long: Nose is intensely coffee, but not super-nice roasted coffee beans, more like burying your nose is a used and still wet coffee filter.  Taste has some vanilla, a lot of used wet coffee leftover from a coffee filter, a lot of lactose, some fresh tobacco leafs.  This beer is absurdly and overly milky.  Basically this beer tastes like chewing on a used coffee filter while drinking a glass of milk, yep, that much fun.  Drinking a full 750ml by myself was almost impossible.  I thought that beer was just wrong.  That beer sucks, I typed the entire rating using only my middle fingers.
Thanks Andy! Espresso up front in the nose. Lots of roasted bitterness in the finish. A ton. And I like it. The flavor is pretty strong. Thick palate. Yummy.
Sampled at an esbls tasting.  Dark with a nice frothy tan head.  A sour aroma that has chocolate.  The taste is big ashes with chocolate.  Cream. A nice creamy feel.  A very tasty beer.
Sampled at ABR this fall. One of the best sweet stouts I have ever had.  Absolutely delicious!

Shared by Matt, thank you very much.  The beer is really strong smelling.  Its fumy and sweet, has some light soy sauce.  It is very sweet and has lots of coffee.  Its a bit astringent.  I can handle the light soy sauce and light astringency in the grandiosity of the beer.  Its full stuff and yet drinkable with just a few small (doable) flaws.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text:
Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Pitch black with thick tan head, leaving lots of lacing behind.

Aroma: Espresso beans, molasses, chocolate, cream and a nice whiff of alcohol.

Taste: Dried out molasses, roasted barley, coffee, cream, chocolate and a light touch of citrus hops. There is also a nice level of smokiness and it almost seems as if it was barrel-aged, but I do not believe that it was.

Palate: Extremely smooth, lush body with low carbonation. Highly warming. Quite silky overall.

Overall: Just incredible. This gives KBS a run for its money. It may not have the Bourbon flavors, but it is just as rich, complex and delicious (if not more so).

750 ml bottle shared by mreusch.  Pour is black brown, with a smallish khaki head. Aroma is nice clean coffee, along with some roast, and really no discernible alcohol heat. Taste starts off with the coffee, then turns to some soy, and gets a bit oily with some cane sweetness and a touch of heat in the finish. Palate starts medium, with lower carbonation levels, then thins out quite a bit and gets oily towards the hotter finish. Thanks for opening this one Matt.

Bomber shared by mreusch. Pours inky black with a thin skin of khaki bubbles. The nose is roasty dark malt and coffee, some dark chocolate and a touch of ash. Medium-bodied and oily with a sweet, roasty-dry finish. Sweet dark roast with a lot of dark roasty espresso. This is a tasty beer. Thanks again for sharing this with us Matt.

Sampled on draft at GTMW 2011. Pours a very dark brown color with a large creamy tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of earthy notes, berry notes and something herbal. The taste is roasted malts, toffee, nutty notes, berries, herbs, coffee, smoke, honey. Medium bodied. Nice beer.

My wifes best friend used her ladylike charms to purchase this bottle for me, much thanks to Jenna for the successful effort. The beer pours a black color with a small well retained head and lots of lace. The aroma is roasty and dominated with fresh coffee and a nice sweet malty almost chocolaty character. The flavor is sweet indeed but also really nicely bitter balancing the beer really pretty well. There is a good bit of coffee flavor in the beer and a nice smattering of hops, which makes me wonder what it would have been like a year ago.

750 ml bottle.  Purple wax top.  Pours a very dark cola with a medium sized tan-light brown head.  Aroma of espresso, coffee and rich chocolate.  Taste of espresso, coffee, malt and rich chocolate.  Very rich and flavorful.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle into a Darkness snifter.

A- Big 3 finger bubbly dark beige head, really nice carbonation, really nice lacing sticks to the side of the glass for a while, dark pitch black color.
S- Big coffee aroma, sweet vanilla beans, slight alcohol is present, some cocoa, chocolate, nice roasty aroma.
T- Wow big flavors, vanilla beans, milk chocolate, big coffee flavors, roasted malts, cocoa, sweet bitterness, huge flavors, complex beer.
M- Big mouth feel, roasted, chewy, thick, sticky, well carbonated.
O- Very impressed, Ive heard great things about this beer as well as bad things. Ive had this one for a while and thought aging it would have hindered the beer instead of enhancing it. I was not able to try it fresh but I can only imagine how amazing it would have been fresh. This beer is complex and tasty. Now I feel a little sad I no longer have one in my cellar.

Thanks to StFun for sharing a bottle at the Jackie Os bottle release on 6/24/11. Black pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of coffee, vanilla, lactose and chocolate. Espresso flavor with milk chocolate creaminess and a bit of that green bell pepper character some coffe beers get before a creamy chocolate finish.

Bottle shared with my brother. Dark creamy pour  with very minimal head. Thin and sparse. Aroma was pretty smokey with hints of sweet milk chocolate. Flavor was a tad too smokey for my liking, although it had some lactose milky qualities to it. I good beer but nothing over the top.

Huge thanks to the guys in the tent next to us waiting for GTMW tickets this weekend for breaking this one out, pours a very dark brown with a decent tannish head, aroma was full of chocolate mixed in with the coffee, the flavor is exactly what you would expect, use espresso notes with a chocolate backing, wonderful.

The Dan Journal #461. Tasted 3/28/11. 22oz bomber. Pours kinda thin, yet brown and opaque. Big bubbled tan head. The aromas are all about the coffee! After that, there are dark chocolate and fudgy notes. Full bodied with a nice mix of creamy, mild and smooth lacto stout juxtapositioned against the bitter astringency of the espresso. Good body but a touch thin for what I was expecting. The flavors are definitely coffee dominant but the sweet maltiness also shines through. Its a bit one sided, but still good drinking.

(22oz bottle thanks to Dalzale at the Falling Rock party downstairs) near black with a dark tan head. Nose of fresh sweet espresso and dry cocoa. Quite creamy. Taste is rich, caramel, sweet, vanilla, but a bit stale as well. A great sweet stout overall.

had this in line at darkness day.  out of a 750ml bottle.  Poured into a red solo cup and its black with some off white head.  The smell is of deep dark coffee.  The taste is the same and its very smooth and sweet.  Good coffee beer.

Big thanks to millah (BA) for hooking me up with this one.  I had heard the coffee taste was starting to fade so I decided it was time.  If it has faded, cant believe the intensity of the coffee it it were fresher.

AROMA: Intense espresso aroma, some raisin scent, picking up some chocolate and vanilla.
APPEARANCE:  Poured into a Grump Troll snifter.  Pours dark dark brown with some lighter brown colors visible on the edges.  Just a tad bit of head that dissipates and then a very thin layer remains in the glass.  There is also some lacing and with each pour it clings to the glass.
TASTE: First taste is a warming and sweet and quickly turns to bitter chocolate, coffee, buttermilk, lingering taste of German chocolate cake and vanilla.
PALATE: Silky smooth, yet full bodied.  Finish is long.
OVERALL: Great beer that goes down too easy.  Nearly 10% ABV, you cant even tell.  It is too bad this isnt part of their seasonal lineup.

The beer pours blaci with a nice two finger medium tan head, great retention and lacing.

The aroma is all coffee but its sweet but smooth.

The taste is also tons of coffee. However, its easy to drink, very smooth.

Overall, one of the best coffee beers around.

750ml, purple waxed bottle, courtesy of maximum12. thanks, corey! so after the wax required all my tiger blood and adonis DNA to open the bottle, this one pours a silky, jet-black with a thick, creamy, two-finger, dark mocha head with smooth, drippy lace. aroma is great with huge, roasted, black malts, campfire smoke, tobacco, and smooth, mocha espresso, with hints of oak, dried prunes, smoked almonds, and lactose sugar with a touch of wet leather and licorice as it warms. flavor is wonderful as well the bitter, roasted espresso taking over initially backed by intensely bitter, dark chocolate, hazelnuts, and smoked wood with hints of dark, vinous fruits, tar, and raw molasses with wet leather on the back end. palate is rich, creamy, and full bodied with smooth carbonation and a lingering, roasted, espresso finish. overall, a fantastic brew from surly. i expected nothing less.

Poured from 750 ml bottle into big fat snifter.
nice dark black color with brown highlights. nice mocha colored fluffy head about a solid finger thick. head retention is good as all the way through the beer there was a nice layer of foam that slid around on the top of the beer.

tons of chocolate esspresso and mocha scents. small amount of sweet malt in the back but covered by the roastiness of the espresso and the roasted barley. There is definately alcohol in here, the smell isnt heavy but enough to take note of it. There is a huge sweetness taht carries through this that im sure is from the lactose, like whip cream or sweet cream butter(no not like popcorn butter...)more like sweet butter cream frosting. 

The taste follows this profile. tastes like a triple shot mocha once the dollop of whipping cream starts to melt into the mocha. There are burnt sugar notes and some coffee and roasted barley bitterness. The sweetness would be overpowering if not for the addition of the astringency from the roasted barley and espresso. wonderful little taste play in the mouth. A bit of Vanilla cigar smoke finds a way to place itself in the taste here and there.

This stuff is really creamy and smooth on the mouth. sticks to your lips especially on the last few sips when it has gotten warm. once again, this is like a mocha with whipped cream. its not syrupy like i was sort of expecting, the body is medium to thick, but not heavy.

the drinkability is very high for a big beast like this. i think the heavy sweetness is what makes it the most difficult to plow through. I think oak aging this would rule the universe. just to dry it out a little bit. mmm, delicious.

This is definately a dessert beer. Id maybe have a raisin oatmeal cookie with it for dunking... or a good scone. I guess i could see a super rich dark black bitter chocolate cake, but this beer is so rich on its own, that might just be too much. Ill stick with my oatmeal cookie :)

De botella. Pitch black colour, light brown creamish head. Coffee indeed in the very pleasant aroma along with roasted malt, dark fruit and more coffee. Good filling mouthfeel. Flavour has lots of coffee along with sweet roasted malt, chocolate, some vanilla and spice like (peppery).

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2011 Nose is fresh espresso, some cocoa, a hint of smoke, and maybe a little cereal grain quality.  Taste is bittersweet chocolate covered espresso beans, a whiff of smoke mid-palate, and some finishing bitterness.  Surprising note of lactic sourness that works pretty well.  Velvety, full mouthfeel.  Damn good beer.

Bottle from Moejuck.  Pours black with a one finger tan head.  The nose is espresso, coffee grounds and green pepper.  The taste is sourish lacto, espresso, burnt malt, milk chocolate and bitter hops.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Tasty.  Thanks again Joe!

Bottle. Black pour, nice and relatively large head, dark cream colour. Aroma has rough liqurice, roast, sugar, coffee, asphalt on a hot day, earth, dried dark fruits, espresso, dark chocolate, lactose, slight alcohol, oak and bourbon. Taste has lots of fairly heavy roast, very bitter coffee and chocolate. Lots of sugary lactose sweetness as well. A faint component of sourness underlies the whole deal. Roast and coffee carries it along. Strong liquorice also perceptible. Lots of carbonation and a full, lush body. Hoppy, rather than roasty bitterness. Also some earthy components. Nicely strong and complex. Be on your watch, though! This thing will have you on your knees in an instant, drooling semi-unconsciously on the floor trying to remember what your purpose in this world once was, before Four came along and unleashed its massiveness upon you. I seem to remember it this way but I might have been merely lost in reveries or dreams, seeing as how this was the concluding beer in a tasting amidst pleasurable company, from which I may have dozed off a couple of times (sorry, guys)... A very nice, potent and (for my part) fatigue-inducing beer!

Courtesy of oakbluff. Scott hooked me up!
Pours pitch black with medium off white head. Nose is of sweet licorice, dark chocolate, light coffee and malty sirupy aromas. Very plesant nose. Taste reveals perfect ballance with nicely dosed coffee and sweet dark malts. There is a bitterness to match the sweetness but it doesnt become drying at all. Mouthfeel is super smooth - velvety is spot on - doesnt get heavy or sticky. Aftertaste matches the taste and fades away very nicely. Sadly, Brooklyn Center, MN is a ways away from Denmark..

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 Pours pitch black with a large light brown head. Aroma has coffee, espresso, huge sweetness as well, smells velvety, vanilla and caramel, vanilla soft ice. And of course tons of roasted malts. A wee bit of earthiness. Taste has the coffe up front, espresso bitterness, again huge sweetness, fudge, sweet vanilla milkshake, roasted malts, wort sweetness. Very smooth, doesnt taste like 10% at all.

Bottle. Pitch black with a thick brown head. Roasty aroma with notes of milk chocolate, fresh grounded coffee, leather and asphalt. I think the body is rather light compared to the alcohol percent. Its sweet with a roasty finish and little bitter, but it is balanced very well. The aroma is lovely, but I think the flavour is bit one-dimensional. Overall a fine and very drinkable stout.
Bottle at Plovmands - Thanks. Pitch black - brown head. Coffee, sweetness, burned, berries, nice medium hoppy, high coffee, espresso, licorice, lactose. Very nice.

Tasted on 1/16/11 from a 750mL waxed bottle obtained in a trade with BDR, thanks Brad.  Pours thick oily black with a thick tan head that slowly recedes to uneven lace.  The nose is fresh espresso, creamy, very darkly roasted malt, and a strong amount of dark chocolate.  The flavor is sweet and creamy up front, moving into the more roasted and bitter notes of malt, hazelnut, dark chocolate, and espresso.  The body is thick and creamy with light carbonation and a long roasted and creamy sweet finish.
Bottle @ Plovmand. Black body with a large brown head. Aroma is espresso coffe, malt, chocolate, vanilla. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, milk, vanilla, roasted malt. Nice lacings.

Bottle at Plovmand.
Pitch black coloured with a small beige head.
Roasted aroma of caramel and dark chocolate with notes of pepper.
Roasted flavour of caramel, coffee and dark chocolate with notes of pepper.
Roasted finish.

bottled. Black coloured. Dense brown head. aroma of coffee, roast, sweetness, caramel, flavour of roast, liqourice, coffee,vanilla,  sweetness, herbs and flowers. Medium to full bodied. Fruity and light roasty bitterness in the end.

Bottle. Pitch black with a dense tan head. The aroma is heavy coffee, toffee, sweet caramel, light chocolate, sweet caramel and light lacto. The flavour has loads of coffee, chocolate, sweet caramel, light spices and light lacto. Sweet espresso coffee finish. Great!

pitch dark, smooth small light brown to yellow head.
roasted aroma, almost charchoal, coffee, dry and very tight roasted aroma.
flavor is coffee, roasted stuff, licorice, mild hoppy balance, ends dry, roasted and coffee. excellent.

Pours a near black brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is big on coffee, with roast, chocolate and vanilla as well. Flavor is a bit sweet with all of the aroma components, but mostly coffee.  Very good brew!

Numerous bottles courtesy of Wavers1 <3

My second favorite stout on the entire planet.

Aroma was straight up American diner-style, hand-scooped espresso milkshake. Thick, creamy brown head stacks high and coats your tongue. Goes down ephemerally- its Heaven in a glass and, like all things good, is over too soon. A keg of this wouldnt be enough. Sweet enough to turn anyone into a stout lover.

<3

Thanks to santa for this.  Tick tock tick tock.  Dark pour with a thick chestnut colored head.   Aroma is a blast of heavy expresso roast.  Flavor is much of the same with light creamy body.  A little thin for the style.  Cool experiment, mediocre beer

Bottle thanks to my cousin! Poured a clear dark brown with with a dark brown head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma was full of a combination of espresso and lactose with a bit of backing roasted malts. Flavor starts with espresso and is joined by sweet milk, a bit of light chocolate and a good amount of roasted malts.

Pours black with a small tan head. The aroma has a tun of coffee. Dôme milk chocolate and spice, but mostly coffee. The flavor has coffee, milk chocolate, plum, earthy tones, smoke, clove. Really nice.

Bottle, thanks to my Secret Summer Santa 2010, I finally got around to this one! Im trying to drink up my cellar, so I can have room to start trading again. Pours inky black, with a pale tan head, lacing is spotty to good. Nose is rich coffee, nice licorice and cream notes also, light smoky notes with some duffy chocolate here too. Flavours are soft and moderately sweet and quite surprisingly smoky, nice hints of coffee and tart cocoa too. Overall pretty excellent.

Big sweet chocolate and espresso nose. Taste is very sweet, lots of lactose, bitterness is rather light, lots of roast, heavy espresso, lots of chocolate. Not the type of beer I usually enjoy, but this was decent.

750 ml bottle courtesy StFun. Pours a very dark mahogany color almost black and topped by a smooth head of khaki colored foam that recedes slowly to a thin film and leaving wet spots of lacing behind. The aroma is nice showing notes of roasted espresso, iced coffee, and lactic cream over a choco-caramel malt base. The flavor follows suit with the sweet iced coffee, cream and milk sugar, which add to the lactic and milky overtone. Chocolate cake, caramel, and roasted espresso follow, which adds nice depth to the brew. Not as roasty or smokey as I was hoping for though. Medium bodied with balanced carbonation and a milky mouthfeel that leads to a dry coffee finish. This is a really nice coffee stout, but I expected a bit more.

Big thanks to two generous Minnesota traders for getting me out bottles of this.

A: Wow! Pours very dark with a huge, billowing cream-colored head that lasts for quite some time and leaves behind multiple rings of sticky lacing.

S: Very nice dry roasted malt scent comes up behind an overwhelming force of espresso. Some creamy sweetness in the background, but the espresso beans really just take this one over.

T: Similar to the nose, although the lactose definitely makes a bit more of an appearance here, lending some sweetness behind the competing sources of roasted character.

M: A bit too dry and harsh, something which I would think the lactose could lighten up a bit.

D: Not the best, as the flavors dont really work together. This is certainly a coffee bomb, which I ordinarily like, but think it pales in comparison to some of the best Ive had. It doesnt quite have the expressive hop character of fresh FBS, nor does it have the smooth creaminess that comes alongside the coffee character with Bullfrogs Double Coffee Stout.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-18-2010

On tap and house-logo snifter served during the 4th Annual Darkness Release Party at the Bavarian Lodge in Lisle, IL.. Dispensed with a black/brown hue, creamy and lasting, deep tan head foam, and clingy ribbons and spots of lacing. The nose was rich and roasty, with coffee and hints of vanilla. The flavor continued the espresso theme, along with pronounced hop bitterness, subtlely masked alcohol warmth,  some light woodiness and smoke, and a nice, creamy mouthfeel, in a rich, full body. Well crafted and an excellent anniversary brew!

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2010 From Notes.  Bought almost a case of this.  Pours black with dark head, fades quick.  Nose is all coffee, some bitter and roasty malts.  Flavor is subtle smoke, bitter coffee and burnt malt.  Mouthfeel suffers a bit IMO...almost too thick/syrupy/sweet on the finish.  Overall a great beer, with the malt balancing the bitter coffee nicely.   Wish I still had some.
EDIT: Best Four memory: Splitting a bottle with Armin while waiting in line for our undergrad commencement to start.  Good times.

750ml bottle thanks to Brian.

Pours a deep, deep brown that settles in almost black in the glass with a thick mocha head that leaves very little lacing.

The aroma has some bitter espresso beans and lactose with some roasted black malts in the background.  Plenty of chocolate as well.

The taste is sweet chocolate malts, lactose and a little bit of coffee.  There is a roasty bitterness underlying everything.  Dry, almost chalky bitterness to the finish.

The feel is light to medium bodied, dry and maybe a little thin for the style.

Im a huge Surly fan but this is not one of my favorites from them.  That said, its better than most stouts out there just not quite up to my lofty expectations.  Really pumped to try it.

Bottle thanks to Kan!black with tan cream head, decent sized bubbles. Nose is heavy burnt grains, espresso. Creamy flavor, not like nose, chocolate and light ash without much bitterness. Very sweet flavor, much more palatable, but also a bit cloying in a way similar to the overly creamy smoke.

750ml bottle, consumed at just under 6 months of age in September 2010.  The pour yields a dark mahogany body that shows a clear, translucent outer edge.  A frothy, bubbly, grayish-khaki head is slowly fading, leaving a good amount of wet, spotted lacing behind.  The nose seems have turned south a little, suggesting (albeit very subtly) notes of cardboard lingering in the background.  Fighting through that somewhat stale overtone is a distinctly lactic creaminess, along with notes of iced coffee, dried caramel, and some coffee cake with chocolate icing.  Its mainly sweet, with little in the way of robust roast.  Flavors are again very milky and lactic, hinting at iced coffee and flaky chocolate cake.  Caramel again imparts a dry sweetness.  On the palate, the medium body shows light carbonation and a milky, somewhat chalky consistency that I like.  Good brew, but I feel it might be on the way down hill already.  Drink em if you got em.

Thanks much to arminjewell for sending this one to NC! Id been so excited to try this one and found it another disappointment, alas. Kinda tart fruit in the nose before the espresso and smoke hits, but they tease more than anything else. Nice thick mouthfeel, thankfully. Unfortunately, the depth of flavors Id been anticipating was nowhere in evidence. Instead, the beer was dominated by spent coffee taste without much complexity at all.

courtesty of armin. Pours black with small brown head. Thick and dark. Aroma of huge lactose, chocolate, nuts, marshmallow and butterscotch. Thick mouthfeel leads to a massively milky body. Huge chocolate cake or fudge shake appeal. Roasted coffee and salty peanut shell in the finish. Great stuff. A huge dessert beer that avoids the southern tier cloying issue.

Bottle 750ml. @ home.[ Courtesy of Summer Secret Santa ]. Clear dark brown black color with a average to large, creamy to frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is light heavy malty, roasted, strong coffee - tobacco Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, espresso coffee, dusty, sugar sweet, chocolate notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20100919]

Thanks Armin.  The beer pours to a black body with a tan head.  The aroma is sweet coffee and milk sugars.  Really sweet aroma.  The flavor is sweet milk chocolate, coffee, milk sugar, and chocolate truffles.  The palate is pretty sweet.  Perhaps a bit over carbonated.

Thanks to Armin for bringing the bomber over!  Poured deeper brown with a short cap of khaki head.  The aroma picked up bright and a little bit sweet espresso first and foremost with deeper dulce du leche veins.. light-moderate roast.. wisps of smoke on the back.  The flavor found the same espresso notes the whole way through, with a large dose of milky sweetness around.. some vanilla and smoke accented.. sweet espresso and drawn caramel on the finish.  Medium-bodied and sweet on the palate.. excellent stuff.
dark chocolate, molasses, roasty smooth with a touch of smoke. Rich chocolate, creamy milky body and earthy espresso notes. love sweet stouts.

Bottle shared by Sparky27...thanks Eric!!!  Thick obsidian pour with a creamy latte head.  Espresso, lactose, cocoa, and roasted malt find their way to the nose.  Similar flavor with honey, caramel, toffee, vanilla, brown sugar, and a bit of sour as well.  Kind of like a milk chocolate shake, even with mouthfeel.  Assertive milk coffee stout that definitely impresses.  Nicely done.

A: The pour is a dark, dark brown color with a fingers worth of khaki colored head.

S: This beer certainly lives up to the description on the nose. Lots of rich coffee and sweet lactose on the nose along with chocolate and great roast quality.

T: The combination of coffee and lactose is probably the best of any of this style of beer other than perhaps (non-infected) Cup a Joe. Just a great blend of rich roasted coffee with hints of chocolate and a smooth creaminess.

M: The body is medium with a really smooth, pleasant carbonation.

D: Another hit from Surly. A really well done coffee and cream stout that highlights both flavor components and makes for an enjoyable beer.
22oz bottle pours an opaque black with a cloudy, white head.  Nose is sweet, malty, smokey, oats, nuts, toasted bread.  Flavor is sweet, malty, brown sugar, toast.  Full bodied, sweet finish.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Big and black, with a nice foamy tan head. Lots of espresso and ash, a little sweet milkiness, cinnamon, and dark roast. Like an amped-down version of KBS. Not as ashy or in-the-face, with a decent amount of vanilla, excellent coffee, and sweet creamy milkiness. Ridiculously smooth and creamy in the mouth. Coffee lingers for a long time. Great stuff.

8oz pour @ Binnys (south loop). Very dark, no transparency on the pour, some head, left lots of lace. Heavy on the flavors. Roasted, burnt, toast aroma more noticable when brew warms. Sweet burnt flavor with a moderate chocolate finish. thick velvet body for a sweet stout, just like I like em. This was a nice well done Sweet Stout, by far my favorite of this style.

750mL courtesy of MrChopin. Poured a near black with a large tan head that left huge sheety lacing. Aroma is dark fruit forward like a De Molen stout. Dark cherries, tropical coffee beans, a little green coffee, lots of figs and florals in there too. Taste is just so much thick creamy coffee, mocha, milk chocolate. Rich, perfect creamy palate. No harshness. No wateriness. What a treat!

Wash. DC tasting.
dark brown, mocha head.
plenty of nice roast, caramel malts, med carbonation, lactic elements, milk-chocolate mouthfeel, coffee-espresso goodness, light palate but loaded with good roasted flavors, with some notes of toffee.
Can we say Imperial Sweet Stout or Milk Stout? this is outstanding.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2011 750 ml bottle at DC local tasting courtesy of the artist formerly known as tarheels86, thamk you sir!  Dark brown color, edge head.  Aroma of Hershey bar, vanilla.  Taste is bitter cocoa, burnt espresso.  Top 3 of the session.

Bottle, thanks Mike.  Deep black pour, rocky tan head.  Loads of ashy espresso in the aroma.  Intense coffee and roastiness with a creamy, thick mouthfeel, smooth chocolate tones, some sweet vanilla, and an unexpected smokiness.  Lovely.
22. Thanks mike. Pours black with a loose dark tan head. Big coffee nose. Sticky thick body. Sweet coffee and chocolate mid palate. Vanilla knocking around. Long sticky chocolate finish.

Thanks for the bottle Omar! Nose is of roasted barley, coffee, and chocolate. As it warms up some aromas of hops and dark fruit notes are noticeable. Flavors of dark coffee, roasted malts, dark bitter chocolate, smoke, chocolate milk, hops, and dark fruit notes as it warms up. Going back and forth with roasted flavors and sweetness with hints of dark fruit in between and ending sweet with a roasty finish touched by some sweetness. Leaves a sticky mouth feel with a roasty sweet finish. The lactose sugar gave this stout a nice body that was medium. Nice way to celebrate the 4th!

Good stuff here!  Shared at the last C-bus tasting.  Almost black pour.  Lots of chocolate milk and coffee in the aroma.  Great mouthfeel--creamy and very smooth.  Taste is milk chocolate and a bit of roasted coffee.  The flavors work very well together.

On tap at GTMW 2010

As my palate took a beating from sour beers and high ABV monsters I walked past the Surly booth. Getting an exceptionally generous pour (over a quarter of a liter) I took advantage of the shade to savor a fantastic anniversary beer. I cant wait to see what next year brings. Knowing Omar and company Surly Five is going to be nothing short of solid. I know I will be looking for bottles.

Aroma / Appearance - Fluid black and a little oily the body looked like a cold cup of black coffee. Offwhite head was a little like vanilla frosting. Charcoal, malt, and iced coffee give this not only sweetness but also a dry impression.

Flavor / Palate - Smoked malts (a little like the residual water from rinsing an ash tray) melded with black coffee at the start. Smooth and easy on the palate for being almost 10% I hope I can get a bottle of this to try on a day when I am not stuffed from 20+ generous pours of world class beers. A beer like this deserves that level of respect.

Had this on tap at the 2010 Oregon Brewers Festival Buzz tent. Colour... as black as night (or at least as black as the Surly Darkness!) with a thick tan head. Nose... Nips (the coffee candy)! Palate... my this a creamy-dreamy wench! Loads of black coffee with heavy cream, bittersweet chocolate, a lightly sweet touch and a roasty, long finish with a double shot latte to go! Gotta be the best espresso stout Ive ever had!!

8/14/10 notes:  Taster from bottle, courtesy some very nice gentleman I met at Blue Palms.  Aroma is sweet condensed milk, roasted malt, milk chocolate, light coffee.  Body is perfect for the style:  smooth, creamy, with a long and gentle finish.  Flavor leads with chocolate and coffee, then rounds with a sweet punch full of sweet milk, smoke and vanilla beans.  Elegant; reminds me of Victory at Sea Porter.

Sampled on tap at the GTMW 10 (Madison, WI). Pours a pitchblack opaque pour, maybe some brownish edges, a big light brownish head laces well, stays big. Aromas are cold espresso, a shock to the system with potent raw coffee at strength, bitter and roasty coffee beans, vanilla cream and lactose, creamy blends with roasted malts. Initial is medium to heavier bodied, a good coffee kick, with roasted malts, vanilla, cocoa, a kick of ABV. Light bitterness and alcohol, full bodied moves into heavy coffee, roast, with creamy lactose, light bitterness, bigger toffee and caramel sweetness comes in behind. A bigger beer, sweet and roasty, nice overall. But, the balance seems a wee bit off kilter, big cocoa and coffee, vanilla, creamy silkiness, but it is still fairly sweet.

Thanks JCB for sharing. Pours a dark black showing some light and a two finger creamy mocha tan head. Rich nose with lots of cacao, dark coffee, burnt caramel, blackstrap molasses, and an herbal hop character. Flavor is rich and roasty, bitter grain and bakers chocolate, mild astringency and a noticeable sweetness. Palate is a little bitter with an astringent bite.

Bottle thanks to someone at Blue Palms 2nd. Black pour with a small tan head. Aroma is minerally, coffee, chocolate, creamer, lactose, vanilla. Taste is chocolate, coffee, lactose and coconut. Creamy carbonation. Thick and sweet. Good.

Bomber poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lasting brown head. Aromas of coffee, roasted malt and bitter chocolate. Palate was mediuim bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of dark roast coffee, bitter chocoate and roasted malt with a smooth dry lingering coffee finish.

Draft at Jerrys sandwiches on 8/7/10.

(part of a day of drinking some incredible brews, so this might have downward bias in the presence of such other great beers)

Pours dark black, with hints of brown in the light.  Very little head.

Because of the head, I couldnt get much aroma.  There was definitely some cofffee and chocolate, and then a strange fruity note that I usually only get in baltic porters.

Flavor has some solid sweetness, but then a really off bitter coffee flavor.  I am not a coffee snob by any means, but this was not good.

Carbonation was okay for the style, but I kind of wanted a little more.  Other than that, it was med-heavy bodied and very smooth, not oily.

Overall, a bit of a disappointment.  I was hoping for the second coming of Depth charge (one of my favorite beers of 2009), but it didnt live up to my expectations.

Was not prepared to pay this much for any bomber on this day, but sales guy talked me into it because he had just sampled. Thank you! Pretty amazing beer. Good strong coffee, a bit of smoke and sweet tobacco, with a very nice dryness at the end. Remarkably smooth.

750 ml bottle courtesy of ncmussell. Thanks Nate. Pours an opaque black with a big tan head that has great retention and oodles of lacing. The aroma is earthy with coffee, espresso, molasses and burnt toast. The flavor is vibrant with coffee, dark biter chocolate, biter walnuts, smoked malts and tar. The palate is full, smooth and creamy with soft carbonation. The finish is long and dry with lingering biter dark chocolate. Overall: Reading the other reviews I kind of expected not to like this beer very much, but as it turns out--it rocks. I love you surly.

bottle shared by rusty on 6/6/10.

brick red shade of blackish brown with a small tan head.

lots of crushed coffee beans in the nose... cream, roast, smoke and caramel all show up as well.

the flavor is a little sweet, a little green peppery and really quite spicy along with notes of caramel, toasted nuts, roast, chocolate and tons of coffee.

it is a bit thick, rich and sweet. intensely of coffee...8/4/7/4/15/3.8

Bottle secured in a complicated arrangement with JCB and a third party.  Ha.  Pours dark brown with a light brown head.  Nose and taste of bitter coffee, sort of like coffee grounds, yet at the same time very sweet from the milk sugars.  Light palate.  Seems like it should be so good, but somehow comes across simple and disappointing.
Not too good. Spent coffee grains and again way too sweet.  Meh.  Seventy five characters, this beer aint worth it.

Draft at OBF Buzz Tent, pours dark brown with a thin tan head, aroma is roast, light caramel, and coffee. Flavor is amazing, dark fruits, roast, chocolate, good coffee, nice finish. I loved this beer, best of OBF.

Tap @ OBF Buzz Tent...  Poured near black with a tan head. Aroma of coffee grinds and roast.  Tasted very different from the nose, a little less coffee with more of a simple syrup sweetness, cocoa and roasted malts with an added coffee presence.  Gingerbread and molasses lent to a bitter finish.

Black with big, foamy, cappuccino head / Nose of tobacco, molasses and  coffee / Medium to full body, some sweetness and acidity, with good malt balance to the hoppy, bitter, finish / Modest flavors of dark roast coffee, molasses, tobacco, grass, and bittersweet chocolate / Flavor doesnt quite live up to the nose, but still very nice.

750ml bottle shared by Eric, thanks 
Appearance: Pours thick black with a small tan head leaving some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, dried milk chocolate and coffee 
Taste: Smooth mouthfeel of dark malts, coffee and bitter chocolate 
Very nice beer.

750 ml bottle shared by footbalm. Pours a total black color with a medium beige head. The aroma is a overpowering sweet milky coffee with chocolates. The flavor is similar; milky, smooth, massive coffee, sweet smooth chocolates. Very easy to drink and nice.
Thanks to lufootball for the bottle. Thick black pour with a creamy tan head. Huge espresso, cream aroma. Creamy, dark fruit, roasted grain taste. Lots of velvet going on.

750ml shared by the tokyogoat, thanks Alex!   Pours a fairly viscous chocolate brown with a 2 finger thick beige head, spotty lacing.  Amazing nose of espresso, bittersweet chocolate and a faint touch of booze.  A simply amazing brew......

Shared by bhensonb. Pours dark brown with no head, just a few tan bubbles, and a marvelous coffee and smoke aroma. The flavor is mostly coffee with a little chocolate and a slightly sour finish, leaving a dry bitterness on the palate.

Bomber from Guerde. Much appreciated. Pours black/brown with a slight tan head. Aroma is strongly coffee and smokey. Full bodied; mild carbonation. Smooth, lightly sweet chocolate and heavy coffee. Could be vanilla. Smoke lurks throughout. Finishes smooth, burnt  malt, coffee, etc. Very good stuff.

courtesy of tyto, thanks again homie! great pour with any amount of creamy brown head you desire. the aroma is huge, fine espresso, not black cheap coffee. tons of creaminess comes through in the aroma some how. the taste is super espresso, some thick blackstrap, a bit of bitter tary tobacco hidden in there, but the sweet creamy vanilla latte is the main component of this brew, letting other subtle notes shine through nicely. the bosy is of course more creamy than creamily possible, and super smooth, goes down way too easy. no hint of alcohol anywhere, amazing stuff.

Thanks to Dstructo for the brew. aroma opens with expresso coffee, chocalate. pours a dark black, light brown head.Has a strong expresso taste. real sweet. great coffee bean aftertaste. has a medium mouthfeel with an decent warming ability. This beer is great.

Bottle courtesy of skyview. Pours a dark black color with a big thick foamy tan head. Nose is roasted notes with lots of lactic notes and chocolate. Palate is creamy, silky smooth with a nice light finish. Flavors are heavy with lactic notes and coffee with some dry chocolate mixed throughout.

shared 750ml bottle thanks to Tharreld.  pours a dark black with a 1/4" tan frothy head.  Huge sweet nose with lots of espresso, chocolate and smoked malts.  Big full body with smooth notes of chocolate, milk, coffee and layers of dark fruits.  A nice hint of smoke lingers towards the top of the mouth.  Excellent espresso finish with a light bitterness.  A licorice and slight alcohol overtone coat the throat.  An absolute beauty... great coffee stout with lots of interesting layers.

Bottle. Aroma is an espresso bomb with chocolate covered cherries and toffee. Pours a very dark red-brown with a small tan head. Flavor is espresso, sweet coffee, and slight burnt bitterness. Med/full mouthfeel with nice warmth. If you like coffee, youll love this.

Big ups to rustychiles for opening this one.  Pours a roasted coffee color with a thin mocha head.  Loaded with smoke and spice, which are likely from the espresso.  Tons of coffee in the flavor, but not without a waxy plastic element that keeps this from being great.

Stumbled upon this by accident but what a lucky find.. Black body.  Rather large light brown head. Tons of lacing.  Fantastic aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and toasted malt.  Flavor is pretty much the same. Starts of rather sweet with a dry roasted coffee finish.

Bottle. Pours a nice deep frothy black color with a full head and a good amount of lacing. Flavor is sweet and malty, notes of cocoa powder and malt sugars are prominent. Espresso ice cream in a glass. But only in a good way. Full bodied, the coffee and alcohol dry it out nicely in the finish. Well done, I think this is the best Surly anniversary beer yet.

Bottle courtesy of tytoanderso pours a brown with a light brown head aroma is fresh espresso roast coffee beans chocolate cocoa. Flavor is all espresso harsh bitter and a little lactic. Very good. Thanks tyler.

750ml bottle from the man, the myth, the legend tytoanderso!  Rating #800.  Pours dark brown with a large creamy tan head that leaves spotty sheets of thin lacing.  Aroma is cocoa, milk chocolate, lactose, espresso, some general roasted malts, and a little vanilla.  Flavor is more cocoa, chocolate, espresso, and lactose.  Very drinkable, tasty stuff, thanks again Tyler, you rock!

Thanks to cloudskipper.  Quite good, though my expectations were a bit high and it didnt quite live up.  Its a creamy beer, lots of dark roast, lots of coffee.  The aroma blends coffee, chocolate, roast nicely, though Id say coffee dominates, in a good way.  Flavor is heavy on the iced coffee.  Would have liked some more of the cocoa to show up on the palate.

Creamy vanilla and coffee on the nose with nice roasted malt notes with sweet chocolate.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Creamy vanilla with sweet coffee roasted malts and bitter chocolate silky smooth mouthfeel.  Excellent!
Thanks to dchmela.  Aroma of coffee and raisins and belgianyeast.  Flavors are the same with a nice finish.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Jet black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of espresso, herbs, sweet vanilla, and a bit of chocolate. Huge black coffee and espresso flavors, balanced by more vanilla cream chocolate, and a really interesting herbal note. For all of the sweetness and heavy body, the acidity of the coffee brings this right back into a drinkable range on the palate. Really well put together in terms of flavor intensity, balance, and mouthfeel. Well done.

Attended the release party at the Blue Nile on 2/23. 
Poured into a pint glass about 3/4 of the way full with a nice tan 1 inch head. Color is dark brown/black. Smells of dark coffee, bittersweet chocolate, and sweet roasted malts. The first taste is pretty in your face with the coffee very pronounced but slowly smooths out. In true Surly fashion you also get a nice hoppy taste. Medium to heavy mouthfeel which I thought really complimented this beer very well. The alcohol is well hidden and I didnt even realize it was 10%.
A friend and I sat and had 2 each, so I would say this is a very drinkable stout. 
Well done Surly.

Courtesy of Blazer06. It pours deep darkness with nice dark tan head. The aroma is musty malts, dark roastiness, black licorice, dark roasted coffee, slight rauch maltiness and wet coffee grounds. The taste is smooth and quickly running into strong dark coffee along with sweetness and some light lactose. It stays very coffee like and thick with sweet malts before picking up a touch of coffee or roasted drying astringency.

Thanks to blazer06 for sharing this one.  Pours dark brown with tan head.  Nose is coffee, roast, sweet chocolate, and a hint of sweetness.  Medium to full bodied and coffee with some sweet chocolate and vanilla.  A bit sweet, but overall not bad.

Draft at Sheffields. Pours superb black with crimson at edges. Rich, frothy brown head. Nose is big and roasty, not burnt. Light coffee notes and cocoa. On taste, tons of roasted grains, though not astringent at all. Light sweetness in the background helps to balance the bitter notes. Nice alcohol note as well. Coffee and cocoa to finish. Finish is reasonably dry. Excellent.

I had a sample of this at Winterfest in St. Paul, but was able to get a bottle for a special occasion.  Pours dark brown with the typical tan colored head in these bottles.  Definitely coffee forward, with milk chocolate and vanilla accents as well.  For the coffee lover, Im sure this does not disappoint.  Very good beer and a favorite among the anniversary beers Surly has put out.  The only one I liked better out of the anniversary beers was Bourbon One.

750mL bottle, courtesy of MatSciGuy. Thanks, Levi! Pours a dark, chocolate-brown color; creamy, light-tan head with fine-bubbled lacing; an attractive pour. Solidly roasted coffee character in the aroma, lightly green and old-ground like, but generally soft and pleasant coffee note; hints of a lactic character, lightly charred and roasted; well-integrated, pleasantly aromatic, and a pretty solid coffee character, at least in the nose. Medium to medium-full body; relaxed, medium-light carbonation; light touches of alcohol, some creaminess, generally non-astringent; medium-high amounts of coffee ground and modestly roasted coffee (slightly green), first and foremost; lots of milk and dark chocolate, some lightly roasted malts and hints of charred notes; creamy, generous coffee character, but with a slight, old-grounds character, and a touch of green vegetal character mixed in (not exceedingly vegetal, but again not quite the same clarity of roasted coffee of the best coffee-infused beer); solid, dense, with some warming alcohol and a touch of roughness in the presentation; overall an enjoyable, lightly milky coffee stout with some light warming character. Medium finish: roasted coffee, lightly milky, touches of roast and dark chocolate; moderately balanced end.

750mL bottle.  Clear deep dark brown with a one finger brown head good retention.  Nose has tons of espresso and chocolate notes, light caramel and spicy pepper.  Flavor does add some nice lactosey notes to help balance the roast and espresso.  Finish is semi-dry with bitterness peaking at a 3, toasty and coffee-y.  Medium body with light to medium carbonation.  Really damn good--thanks Todd.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Bomber thanks to largadeer on BA.

Pours black with a small tan head and some lacing.

Aroma is great - espresso, roast, and dark chocolate.

Flavor is really solid.  Sweet dark chocolate, espresso, caramel malt, and a little alcohol.

Sweet yet dry on the palate.  Medium-full body with average carbonation and some warmth.

This is a really solid impy stout overall, and I know one when I see one.  On the sweeter side, but thats what the style is going for.

What a great beer!The expresso flavoring mixed in with the stout is a great blend. You can taste the sweet chocolate flavor mixed in and it is almost frothy like an actual expresso. Pours black with a solid forming head that glazes the side of your glass to the last sip. Too bad it was an anniversary beer and will be hard to find again if ever.

Nearly a black pour with a very fluffy light brown head.  Aroma is espresso and coffee heaven!  Smells almost like a hazelnut coffee with some cream and sugar.  Flavor is bitter up front followed by a big sweet dose of coffee.  Rich and creamy and really nice.  Some may find it a bit sweet, but I find it just right!

On-tap at my neighborhood bar, Four Moon Tavern. Poured into tulip/snifter.

A - Pours black, tan head. The head sticks around for a bit and then vanished into a thin ring along the sides of the glass. 

S - Sweet milk chocolate, roasted malts, and expresso notes.

T - Like dessert. Chocolate milk with a hint of alcohol. For 10%, its hidden very well. A nice bitter finish that goes nicely with the sweetness.

M - A little too light for me, light to medium, but not way off. Creamy finish.

D - I drank my pour easily and could have had another but decided not to overload myself this session. One of the better versions of this style Ive had.

Bottle, thanks to Blazer06 for sharing.  Poured dark brown with a thin tan head.  Great coffee note in the nose as well as roast, milk chocolate, and vanilla.  Nose was amazing on this beer nice mellow balance.  Full body with an ultra creamy mouth feel and modest carbonation.  The flavor did not disappoint after the nose, very mellow and balanced.  Moderately sweet with primary notes of roast, coffee, and milk chocolate, secondary notes of caramel and vanilla, I also got a faint touch of smoke on the back end.  Finishes roasted with very mild bitterness.

Black color (a little brownish on the edges) with a quickly fading small head.  Strong aroma of lactose sugar and coffee.  Big roasted barley flavor.  Plenty of espresso.  Good chocolate, which comes out more after warming, along with the milkyness.  I wouldnt say boozy, but leaning that way.
Expresso aroma with a slight chocalate undertone, black body tan head, a balance of milky sweet expresso with chocolate alcohol.  As refreshing as a cold iced expresso drink.

black pour with a thick tan head.
aroma is creamy chocolate, dark roasted coffee. 
starts pretty sweet, with lactose. woody vanilla and cocoa. roasted coffee and a creamy semi-sweet finish with a hint of woody burnt malt bitterness..

I actually had this at Whole Foods of all the places, sucks that Surly is pulling out of Chicago in a bit.  Pours black with a tan head.  Huge chocolate, coffee, sweet aroma.  Thick and sweet, this beer is a desert.  Great flavor, I had to have a second.

750ml bottle to snifter (my favorite one). Aroma roasted malt and smoke along with faint coco and espresso. Appearance is dark brown black with a rich dark tan head that fades to film on top. Taste is more the same with espresso up front with a smoke malty finish with coco in there as well. Palate is slick and chaulky with dry finish.

On tap at Hop Leaf.  Pours a dark chocolate black with a  medium sized beige to tan head.  Aromas are all chocolate and espresso.  Very roasty, and a little mineral quality and light smokiness as well.  Medium bodied, chocolate, cocoa, roast, espresso. Long slow lingering bitter roast cocoa finish with some lingering smoke remnants.  Yum.

Bottle. Dark black pour, slowly dissipating thick brown head and an aroma of rich espresso, vanilla and a little green pepper.  Flavor is creamy mellow espresso, milk chocolate and finished light and thin.  Very good beer, and extremely well balanced for 9.4%; however for my money I still prefer a fresh can of Coffee Bender.

Draught at 8th st grill. Lactose stout aroma with promise of sweetness and a hint of higher abc. Completely opaque with tan head. Rich, sweet with strong coffee profile. Nice finish. Hints of molasses and licorice. Very good.

On tap  Creamy beige head on top of red brown black body. Lots of roasted malts coffee  aroma that open up as it warms. Creamy body. Sweet dark fruits under tons of roast chocolate coffee flavors. Not astringent or overly bitter.  7/5/8/4/15

Tap at Jake melnicks, pours blk with foamy tan head. Nose has chocolate, coffee, hazelnuts, really nice mellow aroma. Flavor is  light, milk chocolate, smooth nutty espresso, mild roast thats actually pretty soft, creamy chocolately finish. Starts getting a bit sweet and staightforward but a well done and interesting coffee stout.

On tap at Jake Melnicks... Pours a darker shade of brownish black with a milky tan head and cola brown edges... Aroma of creamy milk chocolate with tons of coffee and roasted malt. Some dark fruits emerge as it warms... Super creamy and full mouthfeel is apparent right of the bat  which really seem to gel well with the silky chocolate and roasted coffee flavors which never become overbearing or astringent. Really easy drinking due to its silky mouthfeel and consistency.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2010 on Tap at 28 with brunch. Big coffee nose with roasted grain. The nose is almost burned with smoke and chocolate mingled. First taste was big roasted bitterness with some chocolate struggling to to make itself known. No hints of sweetness that I expected from the sweet stout base here, so I dont know what to make of it. There was also a slightly boozy note in the finish. I was a little disappointed in this one, but am willing to give it another go if I can catch it this season.

rerate 9-17-10

I dont know what to make of this. The tap at 28 should have been as well monitored as any tap of this beer, but the bottle I opened today isnt anything like what I had at the restaurant. And the bottle is light-years superior.

poured at cellar temp this is an all-but opaque red brown under a half inch head. Nose is coffee and sweet with the roasted elements of coffee dominating. The sweet is back and big in the taste and the palate is smooth and well balanced with a slightly thick mouth feel and a quick bite from the roasted bitterness at the end. Finish is definitely sweet with bitter chocolate notes and some black cherry flavors as well. No sense of boozieness at all in this sample.  Comes way up in my estimation, but not to the level of a 4. 

Like I said, I dont know what to make of the dramatic difference between this one and the one I had at 21. I guess thats why averaged numbers of ratings are a good thing all round.

Tap at both Winterfest and the Blue Nile.  Dark body with massive head.  Dark malts and espresso on the nose but none of the bitterness I usually detest in coffee beers.  Sweet body with coffee and cocoa dominating some malts.

Draft @ Cafe 28.  Pours a very dark brown, near black color with a finger of creamy brown head.  Nose is roasty and somewhat burnt malts with a heavy espresso element, yet hints at sweetness.  The taste is very rich in roast, espresso, dark chocolate, and faint burnt malts.  Just a little bit of that smokiness.  Very rich and creamy.  As an espresso fan I really liked this flavor infusion.  Subtle, but rich.  Not to mention the swirling pattern of brown lacing formed this really cool picture that I swear looked like the grim reaper from a prior Darkness bottle...  Very cool.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2010 Draft @ Buster’s, pours an opaque dark brown body with brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, espresso, lactose, and light sour milk.  Taste is bitter coffee up front, followed by cocoa and earthy coffee grounds.  Sweetens a bit as it warms along with a tar flavor.  The taste is much better at a cooler temperature.  Finish is bitter coffee with a chocolate sweetness.  Palate is slightly syrupy; medium-bodied.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2010 Tap at Acadia. Thick balck pour with a one finger head that leaves beautiful lacing. Smells like a dessert drink youd order at Caribou Coffee.  Heavy espresso flavor with notes of creamy chocolate. Finish is chocolate goodness on your tongue. Sooooo good.

On draught during Winterfest 2010 in St Paul, MN. Pours an opaque dark brown colored brew with a thin tan head that quickly dissipates to a film top. Aroma of toasted dark malt, dark pitted fruits, a hint of figs, candi sugar and espresso. Taste is medium to full bodied, with flavors of dark pitted fruits, candi sugar, espresso with some vanilla and pear. Finish is slightly metallic and semi-sweet with espresso aftertaste that overpowers an Eisbock profile. Pretty much everything I expected with some extra alcohol warmth after the finish.

The upfront espresso aroma incorrectly conveys the way the coffee is infused into this beer.  The aroma is very heady and coffee beany.  The taste was better than I expected after the nose, and was more complex than i expected.  After being billed as a stout, i wasnt impressed with the wateryness of this beer, I expected creamier.

Pours dark black with thin tan head, aroma is full of coffee, candi sugar, dark fruit, and smoke.  Taste is huge espresso, coffee, dark fruit, toffee, and finishes with a nice roasted and smoky finish.  Sweet but bitter, and an excellent creamy mouthfeel.

Tap. Very dark pour. Aroma of cold coffee and olive - very sharp. Taste is nearly coffee grounds. Some chocolate, not sure that the lactose stands out. Nonetheless, great beer. Thanks Omar and Todd, thanks Al!

Winterfest 2010.  I was disappointed they decided to do a coffee bee for Four , as they already have Coffee Bender, and that is a great beer already.  Coffee aroma.  Dark brown color.  Flavor has coffee, but not as much as coffee bender.   Smooth, and an slicky, oily texture.  Some alcohol in this one.  Lightly sweet malt, and it is well balanced, and of course well made.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2010 surly four was my pick for the snowshoe award at winterfest 2010, too bad it lost.  pours deep black with heavy creamy tan head.  nose is sweetness, coffee and fig.  mouthfeel is very smooth and a little heavier.   taste is amazing and complex.  coffee isnt as pronounced as i would have liked, but enough that you know its there.  fairly sweet with candy sugars along dark fruit and fig.  Leaves a little dry bit afterwards, like it was wood-aged.  tastes similar to darkness without  the hops.  one of my new all time favorites.  looking forward to the bottle release and cellaring some.

Pours an opaque, thick chocolate brown with a thin but solid layer of tan-colored head. Aroma is a mix of raisin and fig with chocolate vanilla notes. Flavor is not as sweet as the aroma. A mix of chocolate and dark coffee. Mild licorice notes. Boyd is creamy with light carbonation.
